text: I was manually looking at an old horse racing data file yesterday. With over 12 hours to go before the race, someone would trade roughly £60 on the favourite every 15 minutes. Why would they do that?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: I was manually looking at an old horse racing data file yesterday. With over 12 hours to go before the race, someone would trade roughly £60 on the favourite every 15 minutes. Why would they do that?

text: if you assume the market is (most) accurate at post time then theoretically 12 hours away from the post time seems like a good time to get some value

elements.text: if you assume the market is (most) accurate at post time then theoretically 12 hours away from the post time seems like a good time to get some value

text: Yes, but it's only an assumption that they are profitable. Everyone has their own system, but it doesn't make them right :wink:

elements.text: Yes, but it's only an assumption that they are profitable. Everyone has their own system, but it doesn't make them right

text: £60 every 15 minutes for 12 hours adds up to quite a lump if their method is junk. Assuming its all the same person and they they don't consolidate their position of course. I've always thought that if you had a good model price, then getting in early if the price is value was a good thing - but a lot of you here tell me that is not what the "big" boys do as it will drag the price down because of their action. I guess it depends on the amounts you want to get matched for at the end of the day.

text: This is what I don't understand about it though - if I soak up available money backing a random runner (say between 10.0 and 20.0) for a couple of hundred quid 10 hours before a race starts and that is sufficient to drag a price down significantly it suggests that the market is really dumb. For sure I understand that if you are wanting to get matched for tens of thousands you need to wait for the available money to arrive.

text: That is an interesting question but you have to assume "yes" but in ways that would be unknown to all but a very few. Imagine the horse travels badly on the way to the venue and has been upset significantly - this could have a huge impact but might only manifest itself in horse body language later. And that would need to be seen by skilled horse readers and only a few of those would notice it prior to parading.

text: <@U01B8031PM1> That is kind of what I am getting at. If I can lump on a few hundred quid on a donkey to get a price contraction, that could raise the price of the runner I REALLY want to back later for tens of thousands. That contraction has to result in drift on a subset of the other runners (possibly all of them) so if it were that easy, would not everyone be doing it? I talk here of people who obviously have good models and decent probability estimates for horses and that is going to be a very small proportion of the population of people betting on that market (in terms of numbers of participants, not betting volume necessarily).

text: It's certainly true that your money impacts the market but it's worth adding that it's wrong to assume that the best players get the most money on. There are some good players who match a lot but in general getting tonnes of money on is more a characteristic of lower margin players who do it because they have to. There is an inevitable and unavoidable trade off between margin and turnover. Give me more margin and less turnover any day. Also - let's assume that your £60 guy is a winner; he doesn't have to be the worlds biggest winner to make a lot of money. Maybe he's figured out that he can get really good margin on small amounts of money early in the day (which makes perfect logical sense) - good for him, he'll make a killing and no one will even notice. That's smart. This idea that very successful individual players provide the only or best model is total nonsense. Most people, (including most people on this forum) make losses, a few make a little and a tiny number make a lot. None of them need to concern themselves with what the world's top players do, just how they can make a little bit more than last month. This guy could be making a choice that more value for less stake early in the day is worth it to him despite his market impact. That would put him well ahead of the pack. If he's matching a few hundred quid with good margin on every race that's easily £20 per market which is over £250k a year. That would be adequate for most people's needs and would far exceed most players here. How many of the 800+ players here made > £250k last year? How many posting on this topic?

text: For a bit more perspective - for something long established (like my existing non TPD laying operation) I expect to have 1 significant insight/breakthrough per year, which will usually give me an extra 20% or so on those bets. In a good year I might manage 2. So if I was in your position I'd hope that by this time next year your 10p per bet might be 12p per bet. I'd also expect transactions to go up a bit because even though you start by sacrificing turnover finding new indicators usually opens up new opportunities. So overall you're typically looking at 30% progress per year on established operations. Obviously more on something new.

text: this is a fairly academic response. In reality, in the early / overnight markets, the bookies initial price somewhat sets the initial exchange trading price. if a horse that is 20.0 with the bookie should be like maybe 10.0 it will get quickly moved whether you personally put money down or not as it plain as day value. Look at the situation at Musselburgh the other day.  When its a clear pricing mistake simply not touching it at all and praying no one else spots it is wishful, although execution in these markets is hard
